newsitem.title: POLAND: SOCCER-WARSAW'S LEGIA HOPE TO CATCH HOOLIGANS ON CAMERA.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-WARSAW'S LEGIA HOPE TO CATCH HOOLIGANS ON CAMERA.

text.p: Polish first division leaders Legia Warszawa have installed some 20 security cameras in and around their stadium in the hope of catching soccer hooligans, it was reported on Wednesday.
Nearly 60 people were injured during clashes between police and fans at two matches last weekend.
A news report on public television said Warsaw's Legia, quarter-finalist in last year's Champions' League, had installed cameras for their Wednesday match against mid-table Krakow Wisla.
"The cameras are specially shielded so that fans cannot get to them...(but) it seems they are not interested in the cameras so far," a television reporter said during a live broadcast from the match.

On Tuesday, governor of the western Polish city of Poznan ordered that Lech soccer stadium be closed until the end of the season following crowd trouble. Police used a water-cannon to disperse the unruly crowd, following the home side's 2-0 loss to Legia.
Hooligans and police also clashed in the southwestern city of Wroclaw after home side Slask lost to Widzew Lodz.
Poland's interior ministry has called for tougher laws to ensure security at public events after the weekend violence.
